stream_context.summary: Kaze focused on implementing new gameplay objects from scratch. He programmed a rideable, shrinking soap bar and created its associated bubble particle trail. He then began developing a dynamic, cleanable oil slick, experimenting with vertex coloring to achieve a unique iridescent visual effect based on feedback from his collaborator, Biobak.

development_findings.summary: Kaze and Biobak are designing a new star select screen. They decided against using pre-rendered images due to large file sizes (est. 0.5MB per course) and poor scaling, opting for real-time 3D panoramas which are more ROM-efficient and look better on emulators.
development_findings.quote: If we have a pre-rendered 3D scene, it's going to be cheaper ROM-wise. And it's going to look better on emulator.

development_findings.summary: While implementing the rideable soap bar, Kaze discovered a 'Ridden OBJ' interaction type in the original SM64 code he was previously unaware of, highlighting a moment of learning from the original game's engine.
development_findings.quote: What's usually making the shell stick to Mario? Ridden OBJ? There's a whole interaction type for this? No way, dude. What? Alright, I guess we use this.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is using his own custom particle engine for effects like the soap bubbles because the original SM64 engine is inefficient, reloading textures for every individual particle.
development_findings.quote: I have my own particle system the original particle system is really bad because it overloads the texture every time so rendering 10 bubbles like this would load the bubble texture 10 times

development_findings.summary: Kaze is developing a dynamic oil slick that can be 'cleaned' by the player. The planned implementation involves programmatically editing the texture's alpha mask in real-time as Mario moves over it.
development_findings.quote: I'm thinking of a way to make it so that we have a dynamic texture that like cleans itself up... we could have a normal oil texture and then an alpha mask and if you go over the thing the alpha mask like slowly fills up.

development_findings.summary: To create a shiny, iridescent effect for the oil slick without using a normal map (which would conflict with the dynamic alpha mask), Kaze implemented a system that shifts vertex colors based on the camera's angle, a creative workaround suggested by Biobak.
development_findings.quote: Maybe we cannot make this run reflective unless we use a custom look at matrix and f3d lights.

development_findings.summary: Kaze fixed several bugs in his other project, OnlyUp64, including adding the ability to ledge grab and making wall interactions more consistent, allowing players to jump on walls they would normally be rejected from.

context_findings.summary: Kaze describes his thought process as being based on abstract logic and actions rather than a specific language, which he then translates into English to communicate.
context_findings.quote: I don't really think in German or English as much. I think my thinking patterns are more closely to action. Just a bunch of logical contractions. And then I have to translate it to English if I want to talk to people.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes that creating interconnected lore across his separate fan games is poor design, as it alienates new players.
context_findings.quote: Making your story connected to your other fan games that probably a lot of people that play this new fan game haven't played. It's just kind of bad if you ask me.

context_findings.summary: Kaze shares a disturbing experience of receiving a rape threat from a viewer, apparently after Kaze expressed a negative opinion on philosophy. He analyzes the sender's likely motivations on stream.
context_findings.quote: I found a new achievement today. This is the first time this happened to me. I as a male have gotten a rape threat. That's insane. That's never happened to me before.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's design philosophy for the final puzzle level is to make it feel epic and climactic without being prohibitively difficult, ensuring most players can complete it.
context_findings.quote: It's not going to be anything too difficult because people need to be able to beat it. It's going to feel epic, but it's not going to be super difficult.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses frustration with the frequent updates of the Parallel Launcher emulator, finding them disruptive despite acknowledging they are a sign of good software maintenance.
context_findings.quote: Okay, it's objectively a good thing that software is being maintained well but it's so annoying.

biobak.summary: Biobak created the concept and a mock-up for a new star select screen, which involves a small 3D panorama for each level to convey its 'vibe'.
biobak.quote: Biobak had some pretty cool ideas. I've already experimented a bit with it, but I really don't like what I have so far.

biobak.summary: Biobak suggested that the bubble particles from the soap bar should fade to white as they disappear, a feature Kaze then implemented.
Biobak proposed creating the iridescent oil slick effect by shifting vertex color hues based on the camera's angle, and gave final approval after Kaze implemented it.

badub.summary: No specific contributions from Badub were mentioned in this stream.

zeina.summary: Zeina was mentioned to be at work during the stream and later joined the chat, but no specific project contributions were discussed.
zeina.quote: hello Zeina we're making soap and discussing microwaves

key_stories.title: Implementing the Rideable Soap Bar
key_stories.summary: Kaze implemented a rideable soap bar mechanic, a process that involved rediscovering a feature of the original SM64 engine. He worked through several technical challenges to create the desired visual and gameplay effect, where the soap shrinks from the bottom and causes Mario to trip if ridden too fast.
key_stories.challenge: Create a new, temporary platform that Mario can ride, which shrinks and disappears over time.
key_stories.process: Kaze began by adapting the game's Koopa shell riding code. He encountered a problem with Mario not sticking to the object, leading him to discover an obscure 'Ridden OBJ' interaction type in the base game. He then iterated on the visual design, deciding to make it shrink from the bottom up, which required further coding to dynamically adjust Mario's vertical position.
key_stories.outcome: A functional soap bar that Mario can ride, which shrinks from the bottom and disappears. It includes a unique 'fall forward' animation if the player rides it too fast, adding a small skill-based element to its use.
key_stories.key_quote: How did I not know that?

key_stories.title: Creating the Dynamic Oil Slick
key_stories.summary: To create a dynamic, cleanable oil slick, Kaze faced the challenge of making it look reflective without using conventional methods. Following a suggestion from Biobak, he developed a creative solution using vertex colors that shift with the camera's angle to simulate an iridescent sheen, overcoming the N64's limitations.
key_stories.challenge: Create a visually interesting oil slick that can be dynamically 'cleaned up' by the player, all within the N64's technical limitations.
key_stories.process: Kaze wanted a reflective oil puddle, but a normal map would conflict with his plan to use a dynamic alpha mask for the cleaning effect. Collaborator Biobak suggested simulating iridescence by shifting vertex colors based on the camera's angle. Kaze implemented this technical idea, experimenting with parameters and creating a custom texture to achieve a result that satisfied the team.
key_stories.outcome: A functional, dynamic oil slick with a rainbow sheen effect achieved through vertex color manipulation. The effect was approved by Biobak and is ready for the 'cleaning' logic to be implemented.
key_stories.key_quote: So you want me to map different... Wait, just the camera angle or also the vertex position? Because I could just use the jaw and the pitch of the camera and the position of the vertex to generate a random hue and put it on here.
